repnme.cdata!:
Ethiopia - Capacity Building for
            Decentralized Service Delivery Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Capacity Building for Decentralized
            Service Delivery Project for Ethiopia has a satisfactory
            outcome and a low or negligible risk to development outcome.
            Both the Bank and the borrower performances were moderately
            satisfactory. The main lessons learned from the project are:
            1) Designing a project that fits government implementation
            capacity will help ensure its effectiveness and timely
            implementation. 2) Intensively supervising projects with
            innovative designs and a dynamic context is critical to
            address issues that are not foreseen at the time of
            preparation. 3) Setting procurement thresholds too low can
            delay implementation of infrastructure projects. 4)
            Intensive supervision of the design and implementation of
            urban governments infrastructure projects is essential in
            the early years to ensure that works are of adequate quality
            and that funds are used effectively. 5) Conducting periodic
            client satisfaction surveys at facilities can both focus
            staff on enhancing quality of service delivery and help them
            to understand and overcome obstacles in doing so. 6)
            Thoroughly preparing a project monitoring and evaluation
            system prior to the start of a project will ensure that
            stakeholders can track progress towards the project
            objectives as soon as implementation starts.

Ethiopia - Capacity Building for
            Decentralized Service Delivery Project

repnme.cdata!:
Ethiopia - Capacity Building for
            Decentralized Service Delivery Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Capacity Building for Decentralized
            Service Delivery Project seeks to enhance decentralized
            service delivery performance by initiating long-term public
            sector capacity building at the federal, regional, and local
            levels. This project consists of three components. 1) This
            component will complete the Civil Service Reform Program
            (CSRP) activities and support the launch of the full
            implementation phase of the CSRP at the federal, regional,
            and local levels. As a basis for full implementation, the
            government has acknowledged the need for stronger
            coordination and change management, high-level commitment,
            redesign of the CSRP architecture, and the development of a
            process change modality. 2) Restructuring and empowering
            local government will facilitate the process of building
            local governments that are financially sound and have the
            ability and incentives to improve service delivery,
            especially to the poor. This component will address
            financial constraints, capacity constraints, and unclear
            mandate for local authorities. 3) This component will
            strengthen the Ministry of Capacity Building as the lead
            coordinating agency for the development and implementation
            of National Capacity Building Program and sub-programs
            related to public service delivery.

Ethiopia - Capacity Building for

repnme.cdata!:
Ethiopia - Capacity Building for
            Decentralized Service Delivery Project : environmental
            management framework

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental management
            framework for the Capacity Building for Decentralized
            Service Delivery Project for Ethiopia, which finances pilot
            investments for infrastructure rehabilitation to facilitate
            a learning-by-doing approach and to test the feasibility of
            larger scale infrastructure investment components in future
            operations. This report anticipates that soil and water
            contamination, vegetation loss, soil erosion, dust, noise,
            and accidents during rehabilitation activities will be
            possible negative environmental impacts from sub-projects.
            Sections of this report illustrate the specific steps
            financial intermediaries will take in screening sub-projects
            for environmental impacts and assigning them in the
            appropriate environmental category. To determine the depth
            of detail of the environmental impact assessment, the
            potential impacts in the following areas will be considered:
            social considerations such as tradition and sociao
            organization, tenure rights, predominant attitudes toward
            growth, patterns of interactions, and capacity of local
            institutions; health issues; protected areas; cultural
            heritage and archaeological sites; existing natural
            resources such as forests, soils, wetlands, and water
            resources; and wildlife or endangered species' habitats.

Ethiopia - Capacity Building for
